{{Short description|Ethnic group in south eastern Nigeria}} {{redirect|Ibo|other uses|Ibo (disambiguation)}} {{redirect|Ndigbo|the pan-Igbo organization|Ohanaeze Ndigbo}} {{infobox ethnic group |group=Igbo people |native_name=Ṇ́dị́ Ìgbò |image=File:Igbo_Community_in_Nigeria_and_Africa.svg |image_caption={{map_caption |location_color=dark green |country=the [[Igbo homeland]] |region=Nigeria |region_color=green }} |pop= c. 34 million (2017 est.) |popplace = {{NGA}} 33 million (2017)[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ni.html Nigeria] at CIA World Factbook: "Igbo 18%" out of a population of 190 million (2017 estimate). |languages= {{hlist| [[Igbo language|Igbo]] }} |religions= Primarily [[Christianity]], sometimes [[Syncretism|syncretised]] with indigenous [[Odinani|Igbo religion and belief systems]], minority [[Islam]] |related-c=[[Ibibio people|Ibibio]], [[Efik people|Efik]], [[Annang people|Annang]], [[Ogoni people|Ogoni]], [[Idoma people|Idoma]], [[Igala people|Igala]], [[Urhobo people|Urhobo]], [[Ijaw people|Ijaw]], [[Ogoja]]; more remotely the [[YEAI]] group within [[Volta-Niger]] }} The '''Igbo people''' ({{IPAc-en|lang|ˈ|iː|b|oʊ}}{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/alex-trebek-jeopardy-pronounciation_us_5bef2bd9e4b07573881e87ce|first=Shirley Ngozi|last=Nwangwa|publisher=Huffington Post|title=Why It Matters That Alex Trebek Mispronounced The Name Of My People On ‘Jeopardy!’|accessdate=2018-11-26}}; also '''Ibo''',{{cite book|last1=Isichei|first1=Elizabeth|title=Igbo Worlds|date=1978|publisher=Institute for the Study of Human Issues}}"{{cite EB1911|wstitle=Ibo |volume=14 |page=223}} formerly also ''Iboe, Ebo, Eboe'',{{cite book | last = Lovejoy | first = Paul | title = Identity in the Shadow of Slavery | publisher = Continuum International Publishing Group | page=58 | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-8264-4725-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yEHVCsSFRUcC&pg=PA58}} {{cite book |title=In the Realm of Ghosts and Hauntings |first=E. Randall |last=Floyd |publisher=Harbor House |year=2002 |isbn=978-1-891799-06-8 |page=51 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T8p8OyMHWTYC&pg=PA51}} {{cite book|title=A Dictionary of Jamaican English |first=Frederic Gomes |edition=2nd |last=Cassidy |author2=Robert Brock Le Page |publisher=University of the West Indies Press |year=2002 |page=168 |isbn=978-976-640-127-6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_lmFzFgsTZYC&pg=PA168}} ''Eboans'',{{cite book |title=The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano |last=Equiano |first=Olaudah |authorlink=Olaudah Equiano |page=27 |publisher=I. Knapp |year=1837 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FXVkAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA27}} ''Heebo'';{{cite book|title=Studies in Southern Nigerian History: A Festschrift for Joseph Christopher Okwudili Anene 1918–68 |first=Boniface I. |last=Obichere |publisher=Routledge |year=1982 |isbn=978-0-7146-3106-6 |page=207 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FYFxE8-uSa4C&pg=PA207}} natively '''Ṇ́dị́ Ìgbò''' {{IPA-all|ìɡ͡bò||Ig Igbo.ogg}}) are an ethnic group native to the present-day south-central and southeastern [[Nigeria]]. Geographically, the [[Igboland|Igbo homeland]] is divided into two unequal sections by the [[Niger River]] – an eastern (which is the larger of the two) and a western section.{{cite web |url=http://www.faculty.ucr.edu/~legneref/igbo/igbo1.htm |title=The Igbo People – Origins & History |first1= Katharine |last1=Slattery|publisher= School of English, Queen's University of Belfast|website=www.faculty.ucr.edu|accessdate=April 20, 2016}}{{cite book |title=Foreign Missionary Background and Indigenous Evangelization in Igboland: Igboland and The Igbo People of Nigeria |first1= Nkem Hyginus|last1=Chigere|publisher= Transaction Publishers, USA |year=2000 |isbn=978-3-8258-4964-1 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=sAY8aQz4ztEC&pg=PA17&lpg=PA17&dq=igbo+in+the+east+and+west+of+niger#v=onepage&q=igbo%20in%20the%20east%20and%20west%20of%20niger&f=false|page=17 |accessdate=January 17, 2016}} The Igbo people are one of the largest [[ethnic groups in Africa]].{{cite book|title=Nigeria: The Bradt Travel Guide |first=Lizzie |last=Williams |publisher=Bradt Travel Guides |year=2008 |isbn=978-1-84162-239-2 |page=32 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fwuQ71ZbaOcC&pg=PA32}} The [[Igbo language]] is divided into numerous regional dialects, and somewhat mutually intelligible with the larger "[[Igboid]]" cluster.{{cite book |title= African languages, development and the state |first1=Richard |last1=Fardon |first2=Graham |last2=Furniss |publisher= Routledge |year=1994 |isbn=978-0-415-09476-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_34ReDEC2hMC&pg=PA66 |page=66 |accessdate=2009-04-12}} The [[Igbo homeland]] straddles the lower [[Niger River]], east and south of the [[Edoid]] and [[Idomoid]] groups, and west of the [[Ibibioid]] ([[Cross River languages|Cross River]]) cluster. In rural Nigeria, Igbo people work mostly as craftsmen, farmers and traders. The most important crop is the [[yam (vegetable)|yam]].{{cite web|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/birmingham/content/articles/2008/08/01/yam_and_the_igbos_feature.shtml |publisher= BBC Birmingham |title=Yam and the Igbos |first= Kene |last=Agwu |accessdate=2008-11-24}} Other staple crops include [[cassava]] and [[taro]].{{cite web |url= http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/282215/Igbo |title=Igbo |publisher=[[Britannica Online Encyclopedia]] |accessdate=2009-02-01}} The Igbos are also highly urbanized, with some of the largest metropolitan areas, cities and towns in [[Igboland]] being [[Onitsha]], [[Enugu]], [[Aba, Nigeria|Aba]], [[Owerri]], [[Orlu, Imo|Orlu]], [[Okigwe]], [[Port Harcourt]], [[Asaba, Delta|Asaba]], [[Awka]], [[Nsukka]], [[Nnewi]], [[Umuahia]], [[Abakaliki]], [[Afikpo]], [[Agbor]] and [[Arochukwu]]. Before [[Colonial Nigeria|British colonial rule]] in the 20th century, the Igbo were a politically fragmented group, with a number of centralized chiefdoms such as [[Kingdom of Nri|Nri]], [[Arochukwu]], [[Agbor]] and [[Onitsha]].{{cite book|title= The End of slavery in Africa |first1= Suzanne |last1= Miers |first2= Richard L. |last2= Roberts |publisher= University of Wisconsin Press |year= 1988 |isbn=978-0-299-11554-8 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=G3VSwvEG4QcC&pg=PA437 |page= 437}} [[Frederick Lugard]] introduced the ''[[Eze]]'' system of "Warrant Chiefs".{{cite book|title= The foundations of Nigeria: essays in honor of Toyin Falola |first= Toyin |last= Falola |editor=Adebayo Oyebade |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H5Lzf7s2M8EC&pg=PA476 |publisher=Africa World Press |year=2003 |isbn=978-1-59221-120-3 |page=476 |accessdate=2010-06-27}} Unaffected by the [[Fulani War]] and the resulting spread of Islam in Nigeria in the 19th century, they became overwhelmingly [[Christianity in Nigeria|Christian]] under colonization. In the wake of [[decolonisation]], the Igbo developed a strong sense of ethnic identity. During the [[Nigerian Civil War]] of 1967–1970 the Igbo territories seceded as the short-lived [[Republic of Biafra]].{{cite book |last=Forsythe |first=Frederick |year=2006 |title=Shadows: Airlift and Airwar in Biafra and Nigeria 1967–1970 |page=1 |isbn=978-1-902109-63-3}} [[MASSOB]], a sectarian organization formed in 1999, continues a non-violent struggle for an independent Igbo state.{{cite book|title=The "civil society" problematique: deconstructing civility and southern Nigeria's ethnic radicalization |first=Adedayo Oluwakayode |last=Adekson |publisher=Routledge |year=2004 |isbn=978-0-415-94785-5 |pages=87, 96}} Small ethnic Igbo populations are found in [[Cameroon]]{{cite book |title=The Advance of African Capital: The Growth of Nigerian Private Enterprise |first=Tom |last=Forrest |edition=illustrated |publisher=Edinburgh University Press |year=1994 |isbn=978-0-7486-0492-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i0NinkShiHYC&pg=PA272 |page=272}} and [[Equatorial Guinea]],{{cite book |title=African Countries: An Introduction with Maps |first=Godfrey |last=Mwakikagile |publisher=Pan-African Books: Continental Press |year=2006 |isbn=978-0-620-34815-7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gE2iP2KSnmMC&pg=PA86 |page=86}} as well as outside Africa. == Definition and subgroups == {{Igbo people}} "Igbo" as an ethnic identity developed comparatively recently, in the context of [[decolonisation]] and the [[Nigerian Civil War]]. The various Igbo-speaking communities were historically fragmented and decentralised;{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of World Cultures |page=120 |first=David |last=Levinson |author2=Timothy J O'Leary |isbn=978-0-8161-1815-1 |publisher=G.K. Hall |year=1995}} in the opinion of [[Chinua Achebe]] (2000), Igbo identity should be placed somewhere between a "tribe" and a "nation".{{cite book |title= Home and Exile |last= Achebe |first= Chinua |authorlink= Chinua Achebe |year= 2000 |publisher= [[Oxford University Press]] US |isbn= 978-0-19-513506-0 |page=4 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=BZc25_jgOhgC&printsec=frontcover&dq#PPA4,M1 |quote=...Igbo people might score poorly on the [[Oxford English Dictionary|Oxford dictionary]] test for tribe... Now, to call them a nation... This may not be perfect for the Igbo, but it is close.}} Since the defeat of the [[Republic of Biafra]] in 1970, the Igbo are sometimes classed as a "[[stateless nation]]".{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of the Stateless Nations: S-Z |first=James |last=Minahan |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2002 |isbn=978-0-313-32384-3 |page=762 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K94wQ9MF2JsC&pg=PA762}} == History == === Prehistory === {{see|Niger–Congo homeland}} The [[Igboid languages]] form a cluster within the [[Volta–Niger]] phylum, most likely grouped with [[Yoruboid languages|Yoruboid]] and [[Edoid languages|Edoid]].Williamson & Blench (2000) 'Niger–Congo', in Heine & Nurse, ''African Languages''. The greatest differentiation within the Igboid group is between the [[Ekpeye people|Ekpeye]] and the rest. Williamson (2002) argues that based on this pattern, proto-Igboid migration would have moved down the Niger from a more northern area in the savannah and first settled close to the delta, with a secondary center of Igbo proper more to the north, in the [[Awka]] area.Kay Williamson in Ebiegberi Joe Alagoa, F. N. Anozie, Nwanna Nzewunwa (eds.), ''The Early History of the Niger Delta'' (1988) [https://books.google.com/books?id=MJ7KylvsgYEC&pg=PA92 92f]. Pottery dated at around 2500 BC showing similarities with later Igbo work was found at [[Nsukka]] in the 1970s, along with pottery and tools at nearby Ibagwa; the traditions of the [[Umueri]] clan have as their source the [[Anambra River|Anambra valley]]. In the 1970s the [[Owerri]], [[Okigwe]], [[Orlu, Nigeria|Orlu]], [[Awgu]], [[Udi people|Udi]] and [[Awka]] divisions were determined to constitute "an Igbo heartland" from the linguistic and cultural evidence.{{cite book|last=Elizabeth |first=Isichei |title=A History of the Igbo People |publisher=London: Macmillan |year=1976 |isbn=978-0-333-18556-8}}; excerpted in "[https://books.google.com/books?id=oHt6gmjbpewC&pg=PA75 Cultural Harmony I: Igboland—the World of Man and the World of Spirits]", section 4 of Kalu Ogbaa, ed., ''Understanding Things Fall Apart'' (Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press, 1999; {{ISBN|0-313-30294-4}}), [https://books.google.com/books?id=oHt6gmjbpewC&pg=PA83#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 83–85]. Genetic studies have shown the Igbo to cluster most closely with other Niger-Congo-speaking peoples.{{cite journal|author=Michael C. Campbell|author2=Sarah A. Tishkoff| title=African Genetic Diversity: Implications for Human Demographic History, Modern Human Origins, and Complex Disease Mapping, Annual Review of Genomics and Human Genetics |volume= 9 |date=September 2008|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/suppl/2009/04/30/1172257.DC1/Tishkoff.SOM.pdf|format=pdf|accessdate=December 22, 2013}} The predominant Y-chromosmoal haplogroup is [[Haplogroup E-V38|E-V38 (E1b1a)]].M191/P86 positive samples occurred in tested populations of [[Annang]] (38.3%), [[Ibibio people|Ibibio]] (45.6%), [[Efik people|Efik]] (45%), and Igbo (54.3%). {{cite journal|title=Little genetic differentiation as assessed by uniparental markers in the presence of substantial language variation in peoples of the Cross River region of Nigeria|journal=BMC Evolutionary Biology|date=31 March 2010|first=Krishna R|last=Veeramah|author2=Bruce A Connell |author3=Naser Ansari Pour |author4=Adam Powell |author5=Christopher A Plaster |author6=David Zeitlyn |author7=Nancy R Mendell |author8=Michael E Weale |author9=Neil Bradman |author10=Mark G Thomas |volume=10|pages=92|pmid=20356404|pmc=2867817|doi=10.1186/1471-2148-10-92|url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2148/10/92|accessdate=2010-09-16}} === Nri Kingdom === {{Main|Kingdom of Nri}} [[File:Igbo ukwu bronzes.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Bronze]] from the ninth century town of [[Igbo Ukwu]], now at the [[British Museum]]{{cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/igbo/hd_igbo.htm |last=Apley |first=Apley |title=Igbo-Ukwu (ca. 9th century) |publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|accessdate=2008-11-23}}]] The Nri people of Igbo land have a creation myth which is one of the many creation myths that exist in various parts of Igbo land. The Nri and Aguleri people are in the territory of the Umueri clan who trace their lineages back to the patriarchal king-figure [[Eri (divine king)|Eri]]. Eri's origins are unclear, though he has been described as a "sky being" sent by [[Chukwu]] (God).{{cite book|last=Uzukwu |first=E. Elochukwu |title=Worship as Body Language |year=1997 |isbn=978-0-8146-6151-2 |page=93 |publisher=Liturgical Press |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9hhmzVrYPHAC&pg=PA93}} He has been characterized as having first given societal order to the people of [[Anambra]]. The historian [[Elizabeth Isichei|Elizabeth Allo Isichei]] says "Nri and Aguleri and part of the Umueri clan, [are] a cluster of Igbo village groups which traces its origins to a sky being called Eri."{{cite book|title=A History of African Societies to 1870 |page=246 |isbn=978-0-521-45599-2 |first=Elizabeth Allo |last=Isichei |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LqIVnr9h7DsC&pg=PA246|accessdate=2008-12-13 | year=1997 | publisher=Cambridge University Press}} Archaeological evidence suggests that Nri [[hegemony]] in [[Igboland]] may go back as far as the 9th century,{{cite book |last=Hrbek |first= Ivan; Fāsī, Muḥammad |title=Africa from the Seventh to the Eleventh Century |publisher=Unesco |location=London |year=1988 |page=254 |isbn=978-92-3-101709-4 }} and royal burials have been unearthed dating to at least the 10th century. Eri, the god-like founder of Nri, is believed to have settled the region around 948 with other related Igbo cultures following after in the 13th century.{{cite book | last = Lovejoy | first = Paul | title = Identity in the Shadow of Slavery | publisher = Continuum International Publishing Group | page=62| year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-8264-4725-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yEHVCsSFRUcC&pg=PA62}} The first Eze Nri (King of Nri) [[Eze Nri Ìfikuánim|Ìfikuánim]] followed directly after him. According to Igbo oral tradition, his reign started in 1043.{{cite book |title= Igbo Civilization: Nri Kingdom & Hegemony |first=M. Angulu |last=Onwuejeogwu |publisher=Ethnographica |year=1981 |isbn=978-0-905788-08-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hWm4AAAAIAAJ}} At least one historian puts Ìfikuánim's reign much later, around 1225 AD.{{cite book |title=Murder at Montpelier: Igbo Africans in Virginia |first=Douglas B. |last=Chambers |edition=illustrated |publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi |year=2005 |isbn=978-1-57806-706-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PrPxWLSrp78C&pg=RA1-PA33 |page=33}}
Each king traces his origin back to the founding ancestor, Eri. Each king is a ritual reproduction of Eri. The initiation rite of a new king shows that the ritual process of becoming Ezenri (Nri priest-king) follows closely the path traced by the hero in establishing the Nri kingdom.
- E. Elochukwu Uzukwu{{cite book|last=Uzukwu |first=E. Elochukwu |title=Worship as Body Language |year=1997 |isbn=978-0-8146-6151-2 |page=93 |publisher=Liturgical Press |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9hhmzVrYPHAC&pg=PA98}}
[[File:Igbo ichi marks.jpg|thumb|upright|An Igbo man with facial [[scarification]]s, known as ''[[Ichi (scarification)|ichi]]'', early 20th century{{cite book |title=Among the Ibos of Nigeria: An Account of the Curious & Interesting Habits, Customs & Beliefs of a Little Known African People, by One who Has for Many Years Lived Amongst Them on Close & Intimate Terms |first=George Thomas |last=Basden |publisher=Seeley, Service |year=1921 |page=184}}]] The Kingdom of Nri was a religio-polity, a sort of [[theocratic]] state, that developed in the central heartland of the Igbo region. The Nri had seven types of [[taboo]]s which included human (such as the birth of [[Igbo culture#Twin killing|twins]]), animal (such as killing or eating of pythons),{{cite book |title=The Archaeology of Contextual Meanings |first=Ian |last=Hodder |edition=illustrated |publisher=CUP Archive |year=1987 |isbn=978-0-521-32924-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pv48AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA72 |page=72}} object, temporal, behavioral, speech and place taboos.{{cite book | last=Nyang |first=Sulayman; Olupona, Jacob K. | title = Religious Plurality in Africa: Essays in Honour of John S. Mbiti | publisher = Mouton de Gruyter | location = Berlin | year = 1995 | isbn = 978-3-11-014789-6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fg3wuR95hk8C&pg=PA118 |page=118}} The rules regarding these taboos were used to educate and govern Nri's subjects. This meant that, while certain Igbo may have lived under different formal administration, all followers of the [[Odinani|Igbo religion]] had to abide by the rules of the faith and obey its representative on earth, the Eze Nri.{{cite book |title=The Archaeology of Contextual Meanings |first=Ian |last=Hodder |edition=illustrated |publisher=CUP Archive |year=1987 |isbn=978-0-521-32924-8 |page=72}} === Traditional society === Traditional Igbo political organization was based on a quasi-democratic [[Republicanism|republican]] system of government. In tight knit communities, this system guaranteed its citizens equality, as opposed to a feudalist system with a king ruling over subjects.{{cite book |title=Power, Marginality and African Oral Literature |first=Graham |last=Furniss |author2=Elizabeth Gunner |author3=Liz Gunner |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1995 |isbn=978-0-521-48061-1 |page=65 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1p3nlW3TM-kC&pg=PA65}} This government system was witnessed by the [[Portuguese Empire|Portuguese]] who first arrived and met with the Igbo people in the 15th century.{{cite book |title=Foreign Missionary Background and Indigenous Evangelization in Igboland |first=Nkem Hyginus M. V. |last=Chigere |edition=illustrated |publisher=LIT Verlag Berlin-Hamburg-Münster |year=2001 |isbn=978-3-8258-4964-1 |page=113 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sAY8aQz4ztEC&pg=PA113}} With the exception of a few notable Igbo towns such as [[Onitsha]], which had kings called [[Obi (title)|Obi]], and places like the [[Nri Kingdom]] and [[Arochukwu]], which had [[priest]] kings; Igbo communities and area governments were overwhelmingly ruled solely by a republican consultative assembly of the common people. Communities were usually governed and administered by a council of [[elder (administrative title)|elders]].{{cite book |title=Nigeria's Diverse Peoples: A Reference Sourcebook |first=April A. |last=Gordon |edition=illustrated, annotated |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2003 |isbn=978-1-57607-682-8 |page=37 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H26pO3vwmHoC&pg=PA37}} [[File:A proud trio.png|thumb|left|upright|Three Igbo women in the early 20th century{{cite book |title=Among the Ibos of Nigeria: An Account of the Curious & Interesting Habits, Customs & Beliefs of a Little Known African People, by One who Has for Many Years Lived Amongst Them on Close & Intimate Terms |first=George Thomas |last=Basden |publisher=Seeley, Service |year=1921 |page=96}}]] Although title holders were respected because of their accomplishments and capabilities, they were never revered as kings, but often performed special functions given to them by such assemblies. This way of governing was immensely different from most other communities of Western Africa, and only shared by the [[Ewe people|Ewe]] of [[Ghana]]. ''Umunna'' are a form of [[Patrilineality|patrilineage]] maintained by the Igbo. Law starts with the ''Umunna'' which is a male line of descent from a founding ancestor (who the line is sometimes named after) with groups of compounds containing closely related families headed by the eldest male member. The ''Umunna'' can be seen as the most important pillar of Igbo society.{{cite book|title=Christianity and Ibo culture |first=Edmund |last=Ilogu |publisher=Brill Archive |year=1974 |isbn=978-90-04-04021-2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0uMUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA11 |page=11}}{{cite book |title=Achievement as Value in the Igbo/African Identity: The Ethics |first1=Vernantius Emeka |last1=Ndukaihe |first2=Peter |last2=Fonk |publisher=LIT Verlag Berlin-Hamburg-Münster |year=2006 |isbn=978-3-8258-9929-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ERM77W_wgZYC&pg=PA204 |page=204}}{{cite book|title=Women in Igbo Life and Thought |first=Joseph Thérèse |last=Agbasiere |publisher=Routledge |year=2000 |isbn=978-0-415-22703-2 |page=12 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HdOhY8HqTREC&pg=PA12 |accessdate=2008-12-19}} It was also a culture in which gender was re-constructed and performed according to social need, “where gender and sex did not coincide. Instead, gender was flexible and fluid, allowing women to become men and men to become women” {{Cite book|title=Male Daughters, Female Husbands: Gender and Sex in an African Society|last=Amadiume|first=Ifi|publisher=Zed Books Ltd.|year=1987|isbn=9781783603350|location=London|pages=23}} [[Mathematics]] in indigenous Igbo society is evident in their calendar, banking system and strategic betting game called ''Okwe''.{{cite book |title=Murder at Montpelier: Igbo Africans in Virginia |first=Douglas B. |last=Chambers |edition=illustrated |publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi |year=2005 |isbn=978-1-57806-706-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PrPxWLSrp78C&pg=RA1-PA183 |page=183}} In their indigenous [[Igbo calendar|calendar]], a week had four days, a month consisted of seven weeks and 13 months made a year. In the last month, an extra day was added.{{cite book |title=Childrearing and Infant Care Issues: A Cross-cultural Perspective |first=Pranee |last=Liamputtong |publisher=Nova Publishers |year=2007 |isbn=978-1-60021-610-7 |page=155 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HBnfqWtXDRwC&pg=PA155}}{{cite book |title=African Cultural Astronomy: Current Archaeoastronomy and Ethnoastronomy Research in Africa |first=Jarita C. |last=Holbrook |author2=R. Thebe Medupe |author3=Johnson O. Urama |publisher=Springer, 2007 |isbn=978-1-4020-6638-2 |page=235 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4DJpDW6IAukC&pg=PA235 }} This calendar is still used in indigenous Igbo villages and towns to determine market days.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4DJpDW6IAukC&pg=PA235 |page=35 |title=African Cultural Astronomy: Current Archaeoastronomy and Ethnoastronomy Research in Africa |first=Jarita C. |last=Holbrook |publisher=Springer |year=2007 |isbn=978-1-4020-6638-2 |accessdate=2008-01-10}} They settled law matters via [[mediation|mediators]], and their banking system for loans and savings, called Isusu, is also still used.{{cite book |last=Njoku |first=Onwuka N. |year=2002 |title=Pre-colonial economic history of Nigeria |publisher=Ethiope Publishing Corporation, Benin City, Nigeria |isbn=978-978-2979-36-0}} The Igbo new year, starting with the month ''Ọ́nwạ́ M̀bụ́'' ({{Lang-ig|First Moon}}) occurs on the third week of February,{{cite book|title=An Igbo civilization: Nri kingdom & hegemony |first=M. Angulu |last=Onwuejeogwu |publisher=Ethnographica |year=1981 |isbn=978-978-123-105-6}} although the traditional start of the year for many Igbo communities is around springtime in ''Ọ́nwạ́ Ágwụ́'' (June).{{cite book|title=The Agwu deity in Igbo religion |first=Jude C. U. |last=Aguwa |publisher=Fourth Dimension Publishing Co., Ltd. |year=1995 |page=29 |isbn=978-978-156-399-7}}{{cite book|title=The Jewish book of days: a companion for all seasons |first=Jill |last=Hammer |publisher=Jewish Publication Society |page=224 |year=2006 |isbn=978-0-8276-0831-3}} Used as a ceremonial script by secret societies, the Igbo have an indigenous [[ideogram|ideographic]] set of symbols called [[Nsibidi]], originating from the neighboring [[Ekoi people|Ejagham]] people.{{cite book |title=African Folklore: An Encyclopedia |first=Philip M. |last=Peek |author2=Kwesi Yankah |edition=illustrated |publisher=Taylor & Francis |page=299 |year=2004 |isbn=978-0-415-93933-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pOcWLGktIYoC&pg=PA299}} Igbo people produced [[bronze]]s from as early as the 9th century, some of which have been found at the town of [[Archaeology of Igbo-Ukwu|Igbo Ukwu]], [[Anambra state]]. [[File:Igbo Trade Routes before 1900.svg|thumb|Igbo trade routes before 1900]] A system of [[Indentured servant|indentured servitude]] existed among the Igbo before and after the encounter with Europeans.{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of African History |first=Kevin |last=Shillington |publisher=CRC Press |year=2005 |page=674 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ftz_gtO-pngC&pg=PA674 |isbn=978-1-57958-245-6}}{{cite book |title=The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano |last=Equiano |first=Olaudah |pages= 20–21 |publisher=I. Knapp |year=1837 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FXVkAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA20}} Indentured service in Igbo areas was described by [[Olaudah Equiano]] in his [[The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano|memoir]]. He describes the conditions of the slaves in his community of Essaka, and points out the difference between the treatment of slaves under the Igbo in Essaka, and those in the custody of Europeans in West Indies:
…but how different was their condition from that of the slaves in the West Indies! With us, they do no more work than other members of the community,… even their master;… (except that they were not permitted to eat with those… free-born;) and there was scarce any other difference between them,… Some of these slaves have… slaves under them as their own property… for their own use.
The Niger coast was an area of contact between African and European traders from the years 1434–1807. The Portuguese were the first traders, then the [[Dutch Empire|Dutch]] and finally the [[British Empire|British]].{{cite book |title=The Igbo of southeast Nigeria |first=Victor Chikezie |last=Uchendu |edition=illustrated |publisher=Holt, Rinehart and Winston |year=1965 |isbn=978-0-03-052475-2 |page=4}} Prior to European contact, Igbo trade routes stretched as far as [[Mecca]], [[Medina]] and [[Jeddah]] on the continent.{{cite book|title=McMafia Seriously Organised Crime |first=Misha |last=Glenny |publisher=Random House |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-09-948125-6 |page=200}} === Transatlantic slave (2002) argued that many of the slaves taken from the [[Bight of Biafra]] across the [[Middle Passage]] would have been Igbo.{{cite web |url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~db=all~content=a714005225~tab=content |last=Chambers |first=D.B. |publisher=Routledge, part of the Taylor & Francis Group |title=REJOINDER – The
